column8: C1. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
column9: C2. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
column10: C3. Biodiversity is at risk due to the use of pesticides and monoculture farming
column11: C4. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
column12: C5. Extreme weather disasters affect global food availability
column13: C6. Food waste is a major environmental issue
column14: C7. Food waste is an important social issue (e.g. hunger in the world)
column15: C8. Intensive animal farming and monocultural plantation guarantees food supply
column16: C9. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
column17: C10. Animal antibiotical resistance will be the source of the next global pandemic
column18: C11. Food thrown away is natural and biodegradable and thus not an issue for the environment
column19: C12. The government should ensure that farmers are paid fair prices for their produce to secure higher incomes for those working in agriculture
column20: C13. The government should apply costum duties on imported products that can be produced in Switzerland (e.g., cheese, honey, apples, beef)
column21: C14. Switzerland already has some of the toughest regulations about protecting our environment and agriculture
column22: C15. Strong regulation of food products will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
column23: C16. Food that is NOT environmentally-sustainable, healthy and fairly-produced should be clearly labelled
column24: C17. In Switzerland, packaging waste is a greater environmental issue than food thrown away
column25: C18. Products that employ products that damage the environment, such as palm oil, should be taxed in a similar fashion to tobacco products
column26: C19. Subsidies should only be given to farmers that do not use pesticides or antibiotics
column27: C20. If Switzerland implements strong regulations on importing environmentally-sustainable and fairly-produced food, we would either have to step out of our international trade agreements or have to renegotiate most of them
column28: C21. To give subsidies only to farmers who do not use pesticides is an "extreme" approach that would mean falling crop yields and higher food prices
column29: C22. Restaurants in schools or retirement homes should only offer vegetarian menus.
column30: C23. We should introduce taxes to prevent food waste
column31: C24. Farmers should be encouraged to practice ecologically sustainable agriculture, such as permaculture.
column32: C25. I am happy to buy fairtrade products, like chocolate or coffee, even if they are of lower quality
column33: C26. I am happy to change my nutrition habits, as use leftovers in future meals, if this helps to prevent food waste
column34: C27. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
column35: C28. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
column36: C29. It is essential to always have fresh products available to be prepared for any situation (e.g. unexpected guests)
column37: C30. I don't care where the product I am buying comes from.
